dmca.title: [Fwd: [ABUSE] 1st Takedown Notification [Notice ID: 35006]]
dmca.body:
-----Original Message-----
From: The Planet Policy Enforcement [mailto:abuse@theplanet.com] 
Sent: Thursday, September 30, 2004 4:09 PM
To: Legal Response
Subject: [Fwd: [ABUSE] 1st Takedown Notification [Notice ID: 35006]]

Forwarding to Legal for review.


-------- Original Message --------
Subject: [ABUSE] 1st Takedown Notification [Notice ID: 35006]
Date: Thu, 30 Sep 2004 11:48:19 -0700
From: fox@copyright-compliance.com
Reply-To: fox@copyright-compliance.com
To: abuse@theplanet.com

ThePlanet.com Internet Services, Inc.
1333 Stemmons Frwy - Suite 110





Re:  Unauthorized Use of  Twentieth Century FOX Film Corporation
Property - FIRST DAUGHTER


Notice ID:35006
Notice  Date:30 Sep 2004 18:41:17 GMT
Case ID: 2324042


Dear Sir or Madam:

TWENTIETH CENTURY FOX FILM CORPORATION and its affiliated companies
(collectively, "FOX") are the exclusive owners of copyrights in motion
pictures, including FIRST DAUGHTER.

It has come to our attention that ThePlanet.com Internet Services, Inc.
is the service provider for the IP address listed below, from which
unauthorized copying and distribution (downloading, uploading, file
serving, file "swapping" or other similar activities) of  FOX'S
property is taking place.  The documentation included at the end of this
notice specifies the location of the infringement.  We believe that the
Internet access of the user engaging in this infringement is provided by
ThePlanet.com Internet Services, Inc. or a downstream service provider
who purchases this connectivity from ThePlanet.com Internet Services,
Inc..

This unauthorized copying and distribution constitutes copyright
infringement under Section 106 of the U.S. Copyright Act.  Depending
upon the type of service ThePlanet.com Internet Services, Inc. is
providing to this IP address, it may have legal and/or equitable
liability if it does not expeditiously remove or disable access to the
property listed below, or if it fails to implement a policy that
provides for termination of subscribers who are repeat infringers (see,
17 U.S.C.
